Identifying Characteristics: Green-gray or brown color—can be solid or have blotches on back
Can change its color in seconds—often becomes darker when it is cold or dark or to help it blend in with tree bark
White underside and lots of warts
Bright yellow to orange skin under its thighs
Biology: Breeding season runs from April to August
Males gather in trees and bushes next to breeding ponds and swamps and begin calling
Male aggressively defend its territory from intruders
The female selects a mate based on its call
Females lay eggs on the surface of shallow water in ponds or swamps
The eggs are attached to vegetation to keep them from floating away
The female lays as many as 2000 eggs in groups of 10-40
The tadpoles hatch in four or five days and will change into froglets in about two months
Habitat: Treetops (unless breeding - then found in semipermanent woodland ponds without fish, swamps, vernal pools, man-made fountains and water gardens, and even in rainwater filled swimming pool covers
Diet: Food found in trees and shrubs
Eats moths, tree crickets, ants, flies, grasshoppers, and beetles
Range: Manitoba east to Maine and south to northern Florida and central Texas
